questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P1, delivered a healthy baby girl via normal vaginal delivery. She is now 2 weeks postpartum and presents for a follow-up visit. On examination, her uterus is not palpable per abdomen. What best describes the normal puerperium duration and uterine involution weight in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams

options.label: B
options.text: Puerperium is until 8 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 500 grams

options.label: C
options.text: Puerperium is until 9 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 1000 grams

options.label: D
options.text: Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 100 grams

questions.correct_answer: A. Puerperium is until 6 weeks postpartum; uterine weight - 300 grams
questions.explanation:
Duration

Weight of uterus

Uterus palpable

Immediately after delivery

1000gm (Option C)

Just below the umbilicus

*for 1st 24 hours no change in fundal height. Thereafter, FH decreases @ about 1.25 cm/day.

Fundal height approx. 1 finger breath below the umbilicus on the 2nd postpartum day.

1 week after delivery

500gm (Option B)

Midway between the umbilicus and symphysis pubis

2 weeks after delivery

300gm (Option A)

Not palpable (becomes pelvic organ)

4 weeks after delivery

100gm (Option D)

Involutes completely

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who delivered a healthy term baby one week ago is now presenting to the OBG clinic with complaints of fishy-smelling pale brownish vaginal discharge. What is the nature of this discharge?
questions.explanation:
Type of Lochia

Timing

Composition

Lochia Rubra -red

(Option A)

Seen in 1-4 days
  • Blood
  • Shreds of fetal membranes and decidua
  • Vernix caseosa
  • Lanugo and meconium.

Lochia Serosa-yellowish or

pink or pale brownish

(Option B)

5-9 days
  • Less RBC but more leukocytes
  • Wound exudate
  • Mucus from the cervix
  • Microorganisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci)

Lochia Alba-pale white

(Option C)

10-15 days
  • Decidual cells
  • Leukocytes
  • Mucus
  • Cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells
  • Microorganisms.

questions.text: During postpartum care, a 32-year-old woman who delivered a healthy baby 2 days ago asks about changes in her body during this period. All of the following statements accurately reflect these changes except?

options.label: A
options.text: Cervix becomes firm after delivery and closes by 3 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Patient presenting with retained bits requires manual evacuation

options.label: C
options.text: Woman is most susceptible to cervical dysplasia after delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Rugae starts to reform by 2nd to 3rd week

questions.correct_answer: B. Patient presenting with retained bits requires manual evacuation
questions.explanation:
Cervix
  • Becomes firm after delivery and closes by 3 weeks (Option A)
  • Epithelium starts to regrow
  • Transformation zone starts to reform → Exposure to HPV at this stage → More susceptible to Ca cervix (Option C)

Note: Woman is most susceptible to cervical dysplasia/ cancer immediately after delivery and early in puberty

Vagina
  • Starts shrinking
  • Rugae starts to reform from 2nd to 3rd week onwards (Option D)
  • Epithelium starts to grow by 6 weeks (4 - 6 weeks)

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman presents on postoperative day 4 following an uncomplicated cesarean section delivery due to prolonged labor. She complains of increasing lower abdominal pain, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, and fever. On examination, her abdomen is tender over the uterine incision site, and she has mild tachycardia. On investigation, her WBC count was 14,500. What is the preferred treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features:

Signs:

Investigations:

Treatment:

  • Pain abdomen
  • Dirty, foul-smelling discharge
  • Lower abdomen tenderness
  • On P/V examination:

- Uterine and Adnexal tenderness

  • Leukocytosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old postnatal mother comes with bleeding PV and lower abdominal cramps, 3 weeks postpartum. USG shows an enlarged uterus and tubular hypoechoic areas in the myometrium. The mother is stable. On bimanual examination, the uterus is larger and softer than normal. She is diagnosed with subinvolution. What is the most common cause of the given diagnosis in her case?
questions.explanation:
Subinvolution

Definition

The uterus fails to return to its normal size after delivery.

Pathogenesis
  • Retained Placental Fragments
  • Incompletely Remodeled Spiral Arteries
  • Infection (most common cause)

Clinical features

Prolonged Lochia.

Irregular/Excessive Uterine Bleeding.

Investigations

Bimanual Examination: The Uterus is larger and softer than normal.

HPE: Perivascular Trophoblasts are seen in Vessel walls - Aberrant Interaction between uterine and trophoblast cells

USG Pelvis: Enlarged Uterus with Tubular Hypoechoic areas in the Myometrium. These tubular areas reflect neovascularization and dilated uterine vessels.

Treatment
  • Uterotonics.
  • Methergine (Methylergonovine) 0.2mg every 4 hrs for 24-48hrs.
  • IM dose of Methergine + Infusion of Synthetic Oxytocin in 1L Crystalloid.
  • Suspected cases of Infection are treated with Azithromycin, Amoxicillin-Clavulanate or Doxycycline.
  • Curettage is done if bleeding recurs after medical management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old breastfeeding mother complains of severe pain, redness, and swelling in her left breast, along with fever and chills for 7 days. The patient was put on antibiotics for mastitis but there is no improvement, she also has history of recurrent mastitis. On examination, there is a large fluctuant mass on left side and tenderness is present. What is the next line of management of above conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Drain the abscess, continue antibiotics and consider lactation consultation for prevention

options.label: B
options.text: Stop breastfeeding, continue oral antibiotics and apply cold compresses

options.label: C
options.text: Drain the abscess, start antifungal treatment and wean the baby

options.label: D
options.text: Stop antibiotics, switch to IV antifungal treatment and continue breastfeeding

questions.correct_answer: A. Drain the abscess, continue antibiotics and consider lactation consultation for prevention
questions.explanation:
Definition

Parenchymal infection of mammary glands

Causative organism

Staph. Aureus (most common), Streptococci (option C)

Risk factors

Difficult nursing, cracked nipples, oral antibiotic therapy

Source of infection

Newborn's throat and nose

Treatment of Mastitis
  • Analgesics
  • Hot fomentation with breast milk expression
  • Dicloxacillin, Erythromycin (in penicillin-resistant cases)

Complications of Mastitis

Breast abscess (Variable destruction of breast tissue by recurrent Mastitis)

Treatment of Breast abscess
  • Abscess is drained under LA by giving radical incision in most dependent part and breaking of loculi by finger exploration.
  • Now the cavity is closed with gauze, which is replaced for every 24 hours till the cavity gets healed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, who gave birth 3 months ago, presents with symptoms of anxiety, palpitations, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests reveal abnormalities. What is the most likely phase of postpartum thyroiditis she is experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Postpartum thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that occurs after childbirth, typically within the first year postpartum

Etiology
  • Autoimmune Factors:
    Autoimmune Thyroiditis: Postpartum thyroiditis is often an autoimmune condition, characterized by the presence of thyroid autoantibodies (e.g., anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies).
    Immune Rebound: After childbirth, the immune system rebounds from the immunosuppressed state of pregnancy, which can trigger an autoimmune attack on the thyroid.
  • Genetic Predisposition
  • Hormonal Changes

Clinical manifestations

It has 2 phases which has a clinical progression-

Thyrotoxic phase( 1-4 months) (Option A)

Hypothyroid phase( 4 to 8 months) (Option B)

The hypothyroid phase either leads to euthyroid phase (Option C) or permanent hypothyroidism (Option D).

Investigation

Thyroid Function Tests:

  • TSH: Elevated in the hypothyroid phase, suppressed in the hyperthyroid phase.
  • Free T4: Elevated in the hyperthyroid phase, decreased in the hypothyroid phase.
  • Free T3: May also be elevated in the hyperthyroid phase.

Thyroid Antibodies:

  • Anti-thyroid Peroxidase (Anti-TPO) Antibodies: Often elevated, indicating an autoimmune component.

Treatment:
  1. Hyperthyroid phase- Beta blockers
  2. Hypothyroid phase- Levothyroxine, (25 mcg to 75 mcg)

Regular monitoring and long term follow up of the thyroid profile.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who had severe postpartum hemorrhage two months ago reports fatigue, inability to breastfeed, and decreased libido. She also has noted significant weight gain and cold intolerance. Which diagnostic test is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms
  • Failure to lactate
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • fatigue
  • amenorrhea
  • Hypothyroidism
  • adrenal insufficiency
  • decreased libido
  • weight gain
  • cold intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).
  • MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

Treatment:

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)
